instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936A: What is 820-2936A? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON â€“ CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with water damage. Have no green light and already reflowed the smc. bad trace damage and missing pads on <TRANSISTOR>Q5310</TRANSISTOR> pins 4 and 5. replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5310</TRANSISTOR> and ran jumper from pin 4 to f6905 and <RESISTOR>R5311</RESISTOR> but still no power anywhere on board and no green light.

Also have jumper from pin 4 of <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> to <RESISTOR>R6929</RESISTOR> and pin 1 on <CHIP>U6900</CHIP>.

What to try next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: 3V42 present? PPBUS voltage? If 3V42 is missing check voltage on <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Which pins of <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>? Need all of them, also <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>. No short on 3V42?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
All 3 pins are 0V

No short on 3v42

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Power to <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> comes straight from the adapter so F6905 must be bad or broken trace to <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Replaced F6905 and still 0V on F6905 along with 0v on all pins of the dc in connector. Using a known good magsafe.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Why did you replace F6905, just measure the voltage there. If there is really 0V there then there must be a short somewhere on the DCIN line shutting down the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Thoughtf6905 could be bad since you said if f6905 could be the cause of the problem. checked everything on dc in line and nothing is shorted

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Connect external power supply to magsafe and check current draw. Something must be shutting down the Apple charge with an overload else there would be at least a couple of volts on F6905.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: plugging in external power supply achieved a fan spin and green light. New issue now is ground of <CAPACITOR>C7524</CAPACITOR> is boiling hot. Replaced <CAPACITOR>C7524</CAPACITOR> and but still same issue. Gets so hot that the solder melts. Also <RESISTOR>R7524</RESISTOR> was burned and replaced.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936A</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: I would say there is a short inside the board in <CAPACITOR>C7524</CAPACITOR> area. RIP
